CatDescriptText: Mr. Bert Russell, janitor, 2510 Wylie Avenue, was part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 24, 1959, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think that President Eisenhower should invoke the Taft-Hartley Act in steel strike?" answer reads: "It is only an opening to lead to a settlement. It would ge [sic] good if the President did use it, because he has to get them back to work somehow.  Taft-Hartley is a law, so therefore it should be used."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Bert Russell wearing dark striped double breasted suit jacket, fedora, and eyeglasses, holding newspaper with headline reading "GM Layoffs Top 60,000, New Cars Cut", and standing in front of Beck Shoes and Mellon Bank, Fifth Avenue, Downtown
